required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Adjunctive Treatment of Chronic Migraine Using an Oral Dental Device
clinical_study.official_title: Adjunctive Treatment of Chronic Migraine Using an Oral Dental Device: Overview and Results of a Placebo-Controlled Crossover Study

brief_summary.textblock: Single blinding study comparing FDA cleared device for prevention of medically diagnosed migraine pain to placebo.

detailed_description.textblock: In order to determine if nocturnal jaw clenching can be an influence on chronic migraine pain, the FDA cleared "NTI" (Nociceptive Trigeminal Inhibition) device with the Indications for Use of "for prophylactic treatment of medically diagnosed migraine pain" was compared to a similar device that had no influence on jaw clenching.The HIT-6 (Headache Impact Test) score was selected as the outcome measure, as the goal was to focus on improving disability in sufferer's lives, as in chronic migraine, changes in headache days may not be as helpful as improving disability.

study_design_info.masking_description: Participants were advised that two different designs of device were being compared to each other.

primary_outcome.measure: Improvement of negative impact on life
primary_outcome.description: At least a one-category improvement in subject's HIT-6 score

intervention.description: FDA cleared device for prophylactic treatment of medically diagnosed migraine pain
Similar to Device, but having no influence on clenching intensity

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria: Diagnosed with chronic migraine at a neurology clinic -
Exclusion Criteria: none
-
